author: timbeiko
content: It’s even more expensive than it seems: if this were to happen, you can easily pinpoint which validators are attacking and remove their funds in a coordinated hard fork. For the attacker to do this again, they’d need to obtain 1/3 of the supply *again*, and if they attack, you can fork them out again.

author: timbeiko
content: That alone is pretty strong deterrence

author: symme7ry
content: It seems a bit hard to pinpoint attackers quickly. Let's say that an attacker buys up 1/3 of supply, stakes it, then they start blocking finality. Can you only identify one validator (32 ETH) per block? So could you only slash 32 ETH per 12 seconds, or 230400 per day, or about a billion dollars worth of ETH per day? That's very expensive, but still within reach of USG or CCP especially if the attack caused the price to go lower after a week or so. Or is it easy to identify more than 1 slashable validator per block? I can imagine we can just look at a huge new supply of validators coming online at around the same time and say "these are all the attacker", but it seems like new innocent validators would get caught up in that mix. Maybe with chain analysis you can do pretty good at knowing N validators are all controlled by the same person who just got slashed?

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania

author: treyzania
content: but since they're wrong anyways there's no benefit

author: potuz
content: This changes a lot on Altair, but in phase0 it is hardly the case that you see "wrong" attestations (in the sense that they are almost all valid and have a right source), and you need to include as many attestations as you can, even if you think they are "wrong" cause they weigh in fork-choice and they may become right later. All stock clients include as many attestations as they can pack in a block, although I wonder if the new packing systems have been tested in a highly forked scenario since they all changed since the Medalla incident
